Q: Welcome back, Stephen. I would like to begin by asking you to talk a little bit
about your time in the Agriculture Projects Department, in particular your work with Jim
Evans, the head of the department. What exactly did you do, and what kind of a person

A: Well, I worked in the front office on two occasions. Let me mention here
parenthetically that throughout my career Iâ€™ve always had the problem that when I was at
the operational end I always complained about policy, and when I was on the policy side of

and I would long to get back to somewhere where one can try things out in the real world.
So I yo-yoed back and forth and I worked twice on the policy-making side in the
agriculture department. The first assignment, which was planned, was to work with Jim
Evans very closely on rewriting a number of policies and looking at a number of items.
For example, I can remember writing a piece on agricultural credit, specifically our control
of the reflows to the credit institutions we supported. We were lending money to a credit
institution on terms of up to 30-40 years in the case of IDA credits, or for a 15-, 20-, 25-
year term in the case of Bank loans. Yet, the credit institutions would extend loans for a
four or five year term, and in the case of crop credits even for one year, and was able to
relend the money again. We had no policy or had not even thought through what the  Eccles, 4/11/95, Page 2
implications of this were for the Bank in terms of supervision and control of the reuse of
our funds. So I did a piece of work on that issue for Jim Evans. I must have done about a
dozen similar assignments as well as just helping out in emergencies. But I only did that
for about a year, partly because I was losing patience with doing policy-type work. It can
be interesting to work on a particular problem, but it was very frustrating getting all the
people to agree. I left probably prematurely because my batting average with Jim Evans
wasnâ€™t more than about 60 percent. Probably six out of ten of the things that I did and that
led me to conclude that we ought to make some changes, we would do. And that didnâ€™t
seem to me to be high enough. I did not have enough rapport with him to make it
worthwhile continuing. So I left to be deputy division chief in one of the divisions in the
department.
Q: What kind of a person was Jim Evans? Was he a bit of a constipated bureaucrat?
A: Oh, no. No, no, no. He was very conservative. Not in the sense of not accepting

Where he got into trouble was really not something of his own fault, it was more a

which of low priority so that we can pick the 40 which we can actually handle. Chances

Peter Cargill was an easy sell, he understood what we were trying to do and agreed

doc.repnme: Transcript of oral history interview with Stephen D. Eccles held on April 5, 11, 18 and 25, 1995
doc.abstracts: On April 5, 11, 18, and 25, 1995, Stephen D. Eccles was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Jochen Kraske. During his tenure at the Bank from 1966 to 1994, Mr. Eccles worked in the following areas: as a young professional (1966-1967); in the agriculture projects department as a project officer (1967-1970), as assistant to the director (1971), and as deputy chief to the agro-industrial division; in the Europe, Middle East and North Africa (EMENA) region as program coordinator (1972-1974); in the program and budgeting department as financial advisor (1975-1976); in the eastern Africa region as chief of the East and South Africa agriculture division (1977-1982); in the western Africa region as assistant director for the projects department (1982-1987); in financial operations as deputy treasurer and director (1987-1990); and as vice president and controller (1990-1994). Although Mr. Eccles specialized in country economics, he knew a lot about project economic analysis. His transcript concerns his work on the loan portfolio review, an extensive review of an agriculture project in Tanzania, and the reorganization of the World Bank in 1987.
